repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Mining Sector Capacity
            Building and Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. Lessons largely reinforce the importance
            of Government dialogue, ensuring budgetary and logistical
            support, through an autonomous Project Unit for more
            effective project implementation. In addition, it is
            stipulated that training would be more effective if combined
            with classroom, and on-the-job experience, especially in the
            case of sophisticated geo-science database management
            systems. Also, ensuring continued work flow and program
            development is necessary. Greater care could have been
            exercised in the choice of trainees on these sophisticated
            systems to ensure they are line employees of the relevant
            agencies, rather than contract hires. In line with this,
            capacity building is a slow process, and requires long-term
            commitment from the government, and the Bank in order to put
            sufficient capacity in place. For example, for certain
            specialties it would be helpful for the Bank to fund long
            term academic training. Notwithstanding, the project
            demonstrated that the private sector will respond well to
            invest in the country, and engage in mining sector, provided
            the government establishes the right framework, and
            strengthens adequate institutional capacity.

            TRUST FUND,TF020460-NORWEGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF023410-SIDA CTF FOR ENVIRONMENT,TF023450-CANADIAN CONSULTANT TF FOR ENVIRONMENT,TF026410-SIDA CTF FOR THE ENVIRONMENT,TF031380-BURKINA FASO - ARTISANAL MINING,TF031699-BURKINA FASO - MINING,TF032601-BURKINA FASO - ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Mining Sector Capacity
            Building and Environmental Management Project : proposed
            reallocation of funds and amendment of the  Credit Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This memorandum seeks the Executive
            Directors' approval for reallocation of funds for the
            Mining Sector Capacity Building and Environmental Management
            Project, which would change the Development Credit
            Agreement. A credit for the Project, of SDR14.8 million, was
            approved on June 30, 1997 and became effective on April 28,
            1998. The original closing date, December 31,2002 has been
            extended to June 30,2004. The reallocation of funds will
            allow the project to enhance the achievement in two of its
            principal development objectives: improving the living and
            working conditions of persons involved in small scale and
            artisanal mining, and building capacity to improve
            management of the environment. The reallocation will
            increase consultant services to deepen government
            environmental oversight institutions and to extend work to
            20,000 artisanal miners and their families. These changes
            are proposed: to increase the "Consultants"
            category of the credit agreement by using the funds from the
            "unallocated" category (SDR 1.25 million), and
            funds saved in the categories "equipment" (SDR
            1.50 million) and "training" (SDR 0.5 million).

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Mining Sector Capacity
            Building and Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Mining Sector
            Capacity Building and Environmental Management Project are
            to help: (i) establish an enabling environment to both
            promote private investment in mining and to ensure real and
            sustainable contribution to economic growth; (ii) strengthen
            public and private sector capacity to effectively administer
            regulations and to monitor sector developments; and (iii)
            establish capacity in the country for environmental
            management.  Additionally, the project aims to: (i)
            stimulate private sector response to the growing need for a
            variety of mining and environment related technical goods
            and services; and (ii) identify and adopt appropriate
            mechanisms to facilitate the development of small scale
            mines and to improve the social, health and environmental
            conditions of artisanal miners.  The project will comprise
            four main components: 1) regulatory and fiscal framework and
            training; 2) institutional strengthening and resources
            management; 3) environmental management; and 4) small scale
            and artisanal mining.
